question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
The doctor has told Cal O'Ree that during his ten weeks of working out at the gym, he can expect each week's weight loss to be $1\%$ of his weight at the end of the previous week. His weight at the beginning of the workouts is $244$ pounds. How many pounds does he expect to weigh at the end of the ten weeks? Express your answer to the nearest whole number.
inference:
Cal O'Ree's weight at the end of the first week is $244 - 0.01(244) = 241.96$ pounds.

Cal O'Ree's weight at the end of the second week is $241.96 - 0.01(241.96) = 239.91$ pounds.

Cal O'Ree's weight at the end of the third week is $239.91 - 0.01(239.91) = 237.90$ pounds.

Cal O'Ree's weight at the end of the fourth week is $237.90 - 0.01(237.90) = 235.94$ pounds.

Cal O'Ree's weight at the end of the fifth week is $235.94 - 0.01(235.94) = 233.98$ pounds.

Cal O'Ree's weight at the end of the sixth week is $233.98 - 0.01(233.98) = 232.03$ pounds.

Cal O'Ree's weight at the end of the seventh week is $232.03 - 0.01(232.03) = 230.07$ pounds.

Cal O'Ree's weight at the end of the eighth week is $230.07 - 0.01(230.07) = 228.11$ pounds.

Cal O'Ree's weight at the end of the ninth week is $228.11 - 0.01(228.11) = 226.15$ pounds.

Cal O'Ree's weight at the end of the tenth week is $226.15 - 0.01(226.15) = 224.2$ pounds.

Final Answer: $\boxed{224}.$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: Each week, his weight becomes $.99$ times that of the previous week. Therefore, after 10 weeks, his weight is $244 \times (.99)^{10} \approx 220.6$, so the answer is $\boxed{221}$.
